perturbation.original_text: 4.1 The Company will pay the Professional a base fee of thirty-six thousand dollars ($36,000) per year (the "Base Fee") for Services performed during the Term. The Company shall pay the Base Fee in four (4) equal installments of nine thousand dollars ($9,000) each on March 15, June 15, September 15 and December 15 of each year during the Term commencing on January 15, 2000. The Professional acknowledges that the Company is under no obligation to create or maintain the Products. The Professional agrees that payment of the Base Fee shall satisfy all obligations of the Company hereunder if it elects not to create or market and sell the Products.
perturbation.changed_text: 4.1 The Company will pay the Professional a base fee of thirty-six thousand dollars ($36,000) per year (the "Base Fee") for Services performed during the Term, *contingent upon the successful launch and continued marketing of the Products*. The Company shall pay the Base Fee in four (4) equal installments of nine thousand dollars ($9,000) each on March 15, June 15, September 15 and December 15 of each year during the Term commencing on January 15, 2000. The Professional acknowledges that the Company is under no obligation to create or maintain the Products. The Professional agrees that payment of the Base Fee shall satisfy all obligations of the Company hereunder if it elects not to create or market and sell the Products.
perturbation.explanation: The original Section 4.1 states the company *will* pay the professional a base fee. By adding the phrase 'contingent upon the successful launch and continued marketing of the Products', it creates a contradiction with the later statement 'The Professional agrees that payment of the Base Fee shall satisfy all obligations of the Company hereunder if it elects not to create or market and sell the Products.' It's now unclear if the base fee is guaranteed regardless of product launch or only if the product is launched and marketed.

perturbation.original_text: 9.1 The Professional acknowledges that any use of her name, likeness, image or personal identification by any third party in connection with the making, use, sale, marketing, promotion or advertising of golf equipment, including but not limited to golf clubs and golf bags, would cause a likelihood of confusion with the Products of the Company, during the Term and thereafter during the time the Company disposes of inventory on hand at the expiration of this Agreement. The Professional acknowledges that she will have a right, pursuant to and under the conditions described in Section 4.2 above, to receive a specified royalty for inventory on hand at the expiration of the initial term, and accordingly hereby grants to the Company the right to fill any orders for, assemble components of, market, advertise, promote and sell any inventory of Products in its inventory existing at the expiration or termination of this Agreement, for a period not to exceed two (2) years after such expiration or termination of the original term. To avoid any possibility of confusion of the public, trademark infringement or interference with the rights of the Company, the Professional agrees not to endorse, license or otherwise authorize the use of her name, likeness or image in connection with another company's golf clubs or golf-related clothing or equipment during the Term and for a period of two (2) years thereafter.
perturbation.changed_text: 9.1 The Professional acknowledges that any use of her name, likeness, image or personal identification by any third party in connection with the making, use, sale, marketing, promotion or advertising of golf equipment, including but not limited to golf clubs and golf bags, would cause a likelihood of confusion with the Products of the Company, during the Term and thereafter during the time the Company disposes of inventory on hand at the expiration of this Agreement. The Professional acknowledges that she will have a right, pursuant to and under the conditions described in Section 4.2 above, to receive a specified royalty for inventory on hand at the expiration of the initial term, and accordingly hereby grants to the Company the right to fill any orders for, assemble components of, market, advertise, promote and sell any inventory of Products in its inventory existing at the expiration or termination of this Agreement, for a period not to exceed two (2) years after such expiration or termination of the original term. To avoid any possibility of confusion of the public, trademark infringement or interference with the rights of the Company, the Professional agrees not to endorse, license or otherwise authorize the use of her name, likeness or image in connection with another company's golf clubs or golf-related clothing or equipment during the Term and for a period of two (2) years thereafter, *except for appearances at charity golf events*.
perturbation.explanation: Section 9.1 prohibits the professional from endorsing competing products for two years after the term. However, adding the clause 'except for appearances at charity golf events' introduces a loophole. If the professional appears at a charity event sponsored by a competing golf club manufacturer, is that considered an endorsement? This creates uncertainty and a potential legal dispute.

perturbation.original_text: 10.1 The Professional acknowledges and agrees that a breach of the covenants contained in Section 9 of this Agreement would actually or potentially deprive the Company of a substantial amount of sales and business value and that the amount of injury would be impossible or difficult to ascertain fully. The Company shall, therefore, be entitled to obtain an injunction against the Professional restraining any violation, further violation, or threatened violation of Section 9 above, in addition to any other remedies to which the Company may be entitled by law.
perturbation.changed_text: 10.1 The Professional acknowledges and agrees that a breach of the covenants contained in Section 9 of this Agreement would actually or potentially deprive the Company of a substantial amount of sales and business value and that the amount of injury would be impossible or difficult to ascertain fully. *However, the Company and Professional agrees that liquidated damages of $5000 is the maximum fine for any violation, further violation, or threatened violation of Section 9 above, unless it can be shown that action can be demonstrably shown to be intentional.* The Company shall, therefore, be entitled to obtain an injunction against the Professional restraining any violation, further violation, or threatened violation of Section 9 above, in addition to any other remedies to which the Company may be entitled by law.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause states the Company is entitled to an injunction and all other remedies. The added text introduces a liquidated damages clause as the 'maximum fine.' This directly contradicts the right to 'any other remedies,' including potentially larger damage claims or specific performance, making it unclear what the actual recourse is.
